text:
specialist vs generalist palliative care
generalist palliative care

No standardly accepted definition of generalist palliative care
Treatment service is provided by staff whose main field of work is not in palliative care
The patient situation is less complex than in specialist palliative care
It is not compulsory that the care service is linked with specific structural requirements.

title: Communication in palliative care
text:
Benefits
“Interventions that focus on communication about palliative and end-of-life care, using palliative care specialists, have demonstrated improved quality of life, decreased symptoms of depression, and reduced intensity of care at the end of life.” (Curtis et al. 2013)

title: Communication in palliative care
text:
Side effects

A significant increase in depressive symptoms, with an increase of 2.2 PHQ-8 points.
Depression scores for patients of the most senior trainees were significantly lower than those for patients of first-year residents.


One of the questionnaires most commonly used for the screening and severity assessment of depression in clinical settings and epidemiological studies is the PHQ (Patient health questionnaire). This is a self-reported measure of depressive symptoms composed of 9 Likert-type items each of them corresponding to one of the 9 criteria for major depressive disorder of the 4th edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) (Torre et al. 2023)


Simulation to learn skills for communicating bad news to patients with cancer forms the basis of a 4-day workshop for medical oncology fellows.
This workshop has been associated with significant improvement in participants’ ability to deliver bad news and discuss transitions to palliative care. Clinicians can learn skills for communicating about palliative care in small-group facilitated settings using simulated patients and family members.
A systematic review of communication skills interventions noted the effectiveness of interventions using simulation but observed that no studies have shown an effect on patient-reported outcomes.
We conducted a randomized trial to examine whether a communication skills–building workshop aimed at internal medicine and nurse practitioner trainees, using simulation during which trainees practiced skills associated with palliative and end-of-life care communication, had any effect on patient-, family-, and clinician-reported outcomes.

title: Communication in palliative care
text:
Quality of life

An improvement of TOI (Trial Outcome Index) of 5 points is similar to that of patients who responded to cisplatin-based chemotherapy (Temel et al. 2010)
This compared to the Results from Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Study 5592.
Complete or partial response (95) is meant in contrast to stable (82) or progressive disease (102).
Patients had (stage IIIb and IV) non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), were ambulatory (ECOG 0 or 1) and recieved either:

cisplatin 75 mg/m2 IV over 1 hr plus etoposide 100 mg/m2 IV X 3 (days 1, 2, and 3)
cisplatin 75 mg/m2 IV over 1 hr plus standard dose paclitaxel (135 mg/m2 IV) over 24 hr, or
cisplatin 75 mg/m2 IV over 1 hr plus higher dose paclitaxel (250 mg/m2 IV) over 24 hr with granulocyte colony stimulating factor (g-csf) support (5 g/kg/day).

FACT = Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy
Lung Cancer Subscale (LCS) Physical Well-Being (PWB) Functional Well-Being (FWB)

title: Communication in palliative care
text:
Depressive symptoms

Early integration led to significantly lower (almost 50%) Rates of depression (Temel et al. 2010)
Depressive symptoms were assessed with the use of the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), which consists of two subscales, one for symptoms of anxiety (HADS-A) and one for symptoms of depression (HADS-D)
The PHQ-9 (Patient Health Questionnaire 9) is a nine-item measure that evaluates symptoms of major depressive disorder according to the criteria of the fourth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV).
